entry.content:
Fixing timeout errors with Minecraft

When hosting a server from home, you may notice that some players get kicked due to timeout.
This happens when the Minecraft server is unable to provide data to the player fast enough.
There are two ways to fix/improve this

Solution #1


Are you on WiFi?

Use an Ethernet cable, most internet performance issues are due to bad WiFi. Unless you have the latest WiFi 6 router and are on 5Ghz with a line of sight, Ethernet is the best way to go when hosting a server at home.

If Ethernet is not an option, try getting closer to your WiFi Router / Access Point. Also, if you have other WiFi-enabled devices that you can turn off, give that a try it may also help.

Shut Programs Down

Turn off other programs that might be using your internet connection.
Depending on the technology used by your ISP to bring you internet, other users downloading or uploading data could dramatically affect your upload speed.
If you have a high-capacity plan using fiber, this is probably not a concern (I’m jealous).

Solution #2

 
Lower the amount of data your server needs to send

In server.properties there’s a variable named view-distance.
By default view-distance=10, this tells your server to send world data that is within a 10 chunks radius of the player. If you’re getting timeout issues,

I suggest lowering this value so that view-distance=3. If you want the view distance to be larger, you can keep increasing the value until you get timeout issues again(then subtract 1).

Note after saving server.properties, you’ll need to restart your Minecraft server for the change to take effect.

entry.content:
What is playit.gg?

playit. gg is a networking service that makes it possible to host game servers at home that anyone across the world can join. We do this through our custom tunneling software. You can find our open-source client here. When you launch the playit program, the program will connect to our Anycast Network and assign you a static IP and port. You can then share your static IP and port with friends. When they connect, their connection information will go to the nearest tunnel server and be tunneled to the playit program running on your computer. By tunneling the connection, your friend can connect to the server running within your network.

Continue Reading 

What Data Does Playit.gg Collect?

Playit.gg doesn't sell your data to third parties, playit.gg makes money from donations.

Read The Full Privacy Policy Here

Playit Safty Benefits

  • Your IP gets hidden
  • You can turn the "tunneling" of at any time by closing the program
  • DDoS attacks won't affect your network
  • Open Source
  • Huge Bandwith
  • Better Connection Handling
  • Strong Firewalls
  • CorsssideScripting Protection
  • More than 5K users
  • Updates Regularly

If you are having high ping when using playit make sure that your playit program connects to the closest Datacenter to you you can check this on the playit website

To do this put one of the control addresses at the top of your playit.toml file

On Linux
you can find this file /etc/playit/playit.toml,
On Windows,
it is located in the same place as your playit.exe

The Playit agent should route you in the best way possible.

Updating Zones
Playit routing zones will be updated soon, please contact the support mail.
Thanks for the understanding

Have a bad ping? No Ipv6

READ FIRST
It can be really difficult to update routing.
Routing is something your ISP decides, not us.
There are a few things we can try to influence your ISP to route you better,
but for many, it won't be possible until we buy more IP space.

Send an email to support@playit.gg with the following data:
1) Where you're located (country/city/state)
2) The text from http://ping.playit.gg/
3) Which data center do you think would be best, visit https://playit.gg/about and see the map
4) One of your playit.gg tunnel addresses

entry.content:
Playit should work with almost every game using a custom tunnel, although some require you to either change your server settings or your tunnel settings.

Step One

Create a custom tunnel with your servers protocol (choose both if you are unsure) and choose 1 as the local port

Step Two

Edit your newly created tunnel and change the local port to the random port that your tunnel got 

Step Three

Then change your server port to the same port number, this is different for every game (most commonly you can change this in your start.bat / start.sh file) 

Done!

entry.title: Run playit in Linux
entry.summary: This is the most updated guide INSTALL PLAYIT ON LINUX Pre-Setup: Run the command(s) below sudo mkdir /etc/playit/ Navigate to the page for downloads and…
entry.content:
This is the most updated guide

Step Zero

INSTALL PLAYIT ON LINUX
Pre-Setup: Run the command(s) below
sudo mkdir /etc/playit/

Step One

Navigate to the page for downloads and find the files with no extension
(no .exe or .dmg at the end):
https://github.com/playit-cloud/playit-agent/releases/latest

Find the one (most likely playit-<some version> with no file extension.)
and right-click it and press "Copy link address"

IF YOU HAVE A DIFFERENT DISTRIBUTION OF LINUX FIND THE COMPATIBLE ONE

Step Two

Run the following command: wget <the-link-you-copied> -O playit 
while replacing <the-link-you-copied> with the link you copied from step 1

Step Three

Make the file runnable.
Run the following command:
sudo chmod +x ./playit

Step Four

Move the file to /etc/playit. Run the following command:
sudo mv ./playit /etc/playit/playit

Step Five

Make a service file (run on boot and in the background). Run the following command:
sudo nano /etc/systemd/system/playit.service
In the following window that opens, paste in this text:

[Unit]
Description=Playit.gg client
After=network.target

[Service]
WorkingDirectory=/etc/playit
ExecStart=/etc/playit/playit
Restart=on-failure
RestartSec=5

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target

then do ctrl + x to exit the file, press y to save, and then enter to confirm.

Step Six

Start the service in the background. Run the following commands:
sudo systemctl start playit
sudo systemctl enable playit

Step Seven

Get the claim code from playit. Run the following commands:
sudo systemctl status playit
From here you should be able to get the claim link. Paste it into your browser and log in to start creating tunnels.


To exit this menu do CTRL + C

Done!

entry.title: Setup a Mindustry server
entry.summary: Step 1 - Getting the server jar Mindustry is written in Java, in fact when you execute the Windows executable, it just runs a Java…
entry.content:
Step 1 - Getting the server jar

Mindustry is written in Java, in fact when you execute the Windows executable, it just runs a Java VM that comes with it and runs the desktop jar file.
For servers, however, they only provide a server.jar file and a bunch of run scripts in bash and Windows Batch Executable.
Simply go to the GitHub Release or go through the itch page and press the Download button (note that you do not have to pay to purchase, that’s only the Steam version) and download the server variant of the game
(server-release.jar on GitHub and [Server]Mindustry.zip on itch),
if it’s inside a zip then extract the zip.

Step 2 - Running the server to get the port

If the thing you’re using runs Java and has internet, then it can also run the server jar.
I will be using Windows Subsystem for Linux 2 on Windows 11. 
Open a command line and type something similar to the below:

Notice how after -jar I put the jar file’s name with the extension

Alternatively, just run the provided batch executable/bash script file provided with it if you download it from the itch.

Step 3 - Getting the server’s port

The server by default runs on 127.0.0.1, so all you need is the port, to check (and configure) the port, you can type config, it will show up a bunch of stuff so scroll up until the port section. (in my case the port was 6567)

To change the port, simply type config port <insert port number> and press enter.

Step 4 - Setting up the custom tunnel

Open up your account page, open the tunnels tab, and on Add new tunnel select custom.

Then after that, type the port you got from the server into the Local port textbox

Then click set and that’s all for configuring the tunnel!

Step 5 - Hosting a round and connecting to the server

First, let’s start a round session, on the server console, type in 
host [optional map name] [optional mode arg] to start a round session.
(to get available maps, type maps),
if you do not specify any arguments, the map will be random and the mode will be survival by default.

Download the game (aka desktop) variant, and ensure it’s the same version as the server.
Then launch the game, wait for it to load then click on Play, then Join Game

Now type in your username, and select a team color if you want to be in a different team (the color box next to username textbox), then click add server. Type/paste the tunnel url with the port, click ok, and then try joining it, if it works then you should see something like this:

I hosted the fortress map under sandbox mode in the picture above

Done

And that’s all you need for creating a tunnel for Mindustry in playit!
